comments:
Opening the WSDL editor results in frequent calls to the URIResolver without a
base location.  I adjusted my own extension to report them:

Lawrence, it seems suspicious that there a 'null' baseLocation.  I'm assuming
that there aren't any cases where this should happen ... but perhaps I'm missing
something.  Do you know of any valid cases where baseLocation would be null?

Base location can be null if you know you're passing in an absolution location
to resolve. Does the URI resolver API state that a null base location cannot be
passed in? Is this a constraint we want on the URI resolver framework?

Maybe I misunderstand what "absolution location" means in this context, but in
this scenario it sounds like the client code doesn't need resolution?

Unless a method is explicitly declared to *accept* null value parameters, nulls
are implicitly invalid values.  I'd prefer to go the route of not supporting
null arguments in the API unless there's a valid scenario for calling the
resolver where a null base location is useful.

One scenario is a tool is resolving a resource but isn't resolving it wrt a
file. In this case there is no base location and the location cannot be
relative. The tool may still want to use URI resolution in order to make use of
the XML catalog ,the cache, and other resolvers.

I've corrected the calls to the URI resolver in the WSDL validator to pass in an empty string for the base location when no base location is available.

This fix will be available in 1.5RC2.
